results.title: Talking shop: demands on language
results.creator_credit: Karl McPhee, Tom Manefield, Australia. Dept. of Education and Film Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Watch Your Language”.
A teenage boy and girl, when interviewed for vacation jobs in a store, reveal a limited capacity to express themselves. Describes their feelings about their jobs, their fellow workers and shows how they adapted to the situation. Useful for linguistics studies and career advisers. Suitable for middle and upper secondary levels and tertiary teacher education.

results.title: Talespinners
results.brief_description: CHRISTOPHER changes his name (prod. Tamara Lynch ; dir., animator, Cilia Sawadogo); A young boy decides to change his name many times but soon decides that his original name is just as good. Based on the book by Itah Sadu who also narrates the film. “Lights for Gita” (prod. Tamara Lynch ; dir. Michel Vo ; animator, Gregory Houston); A young girl is excited about celebrating Divali, an old Indian festival that fills the dark with the light. Her excitement soon ends because of a storm. Based on the book by Rachna Gilmore. “The Magic of Anansi” (prod. Tamara Lynch ; dir., animator, Jamie Mason ; animator, Luigi Allemano); Anansi a spider living in the jungle doesn’t think the other animals respected him so he sets out to gain the respect he deserves. Based on a West Indian tale and narrated by Winston Sutton. “From far away” (prod. Michael Fukushima ; dir., animators, Shira Avni, Serene El-Haj Daoud); A little girl tries to fit into a new school in a new country. Based on the book by Robert Munsch and Saoussan Askar. “CHRISTOPHER: please clean up your room!” (prod. Tamara Lynch ; dir., animator, Vincent Gauthier ; animator, Jo Meuris); A young boy manages to scare his family and friends with his messy room. This soon changes thanks to a few friends. Based on the book by Itah Sadu who also narrates the film.

results.title: Reading for meaning: the Goodman Model
results.creator_credit: Karl McPhee, Tom Manefield and Film Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Watch your language”
Understanding the reading process. Professors Ken and Yetta Goodman discuss the problems of the teaching of reading with a class of teachers in Australia. Docments some of their main propositions relating to language in use, miscue analysis and reading. Stresses the need to focus on the strengths of children and not simply the weaknesses.
Suitable for teacher level.

results.title: Tanaka
results.brief_description: When Mori, a young Japanese man, is sent by his family to Australia to oversee the funeral of his uncle, Hiroshi, he is thrust into a world of cross-cultural love, grief and misunderstanding. Estranged from Hiroshi for many years, Mori and his family are unaware that he was gay and lived with his Australian lover Ron for decades. As he gets to know his uncle for the first time through videos, photographs, and the stories Ron tells him, Mori must now come to terms with this fresh knowledge and find a way to fulfil his traditional obligations to his family while remaining true to his uncle’s spirit. A powerful and poignant film. Winner of Best Australian Short, Melbourne Queer Film Festival 2003. Cast includes Morihiko Hasebe, Ronald Jacobson, Chris Bartlett, Ant Keogh, Rohan Timlock, Takuji Hasebe, Yukio Kimura.

results.title: Discovering China and Tibet
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Video visits”.
Discover China, the 5,000-year-old “Middle Kingdom” and mysterious Tibet. The journey begins in Beijing, home to Chinese emperors for more than 500 years. Travel to Xian, the ancient capital, to examine a Neolithic village. Visit the birthplace of Confucius, then trek to Tibet’s mountainous land shrouded in Buddhist culture. Witness the effects of modernisation on the Chinese workplace that has transformed China into an awakening giant.

results.title: Language at twelve (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Karl McPhee, Andrew Frazer, Tom Manefield and Film Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Watch Your Language”.
Intended primarily to emphasise the diversity and complexity of language in the life of a 12-year-old. This film focuses on two 12-year-olds who are involved in a school language project. Shows their interaction with a sufficient number of significant people in their lives for us to gain an impression of how the demands upon their speech shift. Suitable for upper secondary level.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Karl McPhee, Andrew Frazer, Tom Manefield and Film Australia

results.title: Surprising Amsterdam
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Video visits”.
Amsterdam is one of the world’s great cities, renowned for its historic and splendid museums and architecture, and its non-stop and exuberant night- life. The video shows us aspects of both medieval and modern Amsterdam. We are taken on a journey of the city’s famed canals. We visit the flower markets, the Van Gogh Museum, the 700 year old Dam Square, the Jewish section which houses the Anne Frank Museum and enjoy a Sunday afternoon in the beautiful gardens of the Vondelpark. Finally, after dark, we take a wander in the infamous “red-light” district.

results.title: Tales from a suitcase 3
results.creator_credit: Andrea Dal Bosco, David S. Vadiveloo, Will Davies, Look Television Productions and SBS Independent
results.brief_description: This acclaimed SBS series presents the stories behind migration to Australia during the 1950s when many people fled post-War atrocities, the rise of Communism and impoverishment. This tape contains three separate stories. Episode 7: Jutta Malnic, born in Berlin to an Australian mother and German father, had a childhood filled with exotic stories about a country which provided refuge after harrowing World War II experiences. A photographer, Jutta relays her remarkable journey from war-torn Europe and her interesting experiences as an emigre. Episode 8: Victor Vadiveloo was taken from his family in Sri Lanka at age 4 and sent to work on the Burmese railway at 14, before escaping. Upon emigrating to Australia Victor continued his studies in order to become a surgeon, and experienced excessive racism which only intensified when he fell in love and married a white woman. Episode 9: Rinaldo Fabbro, an Italian partisan fighter during World War II who was to become an architect of great acclaim, discusses his past, having arrived in Australia in 1949, in search of prosperity. Some quite remarkable tales emerge about these interesting times, told with finesse by various raconteurs and are an appealing mix of pathos and humour.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Andrea Dal Bosco, David S. Vadiveloo, Will Davies, Look Television Productions and SBS Independent
